page.title: 16HOUSING
page.content: Before 1820 most of the land was owned by the Marquess of Anglesey and there were no houses except one called Lamb Lodge, with a few surrounding thatched cottages which owners of various pieces of land lived in. Some of these cottages remain. About 6 months after a mine at Chasewater called "The Marquess" was opened, in 1849, the manager of the pit asked for some cottages to be built and these were the beginning of Chasetown . As Chasetown became more of a coal producing area many more miners' terraces were built. Chasetown continued to grow around the mining industry and about 1950 the Oakdene Council estate was built. This lead to more private estates being built with the majority of houses being semi-detached and very few detached. All developement has been low-rise.
